values.description:
[Jenkins nvidia](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/518)

This pull request address [this comment](#!/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/1859/issue_1702/diff#comment-9785285).

A latched subscription is designed to receive the last message sent on a topic. The flag that indicates if the subscription has received a latched message is only set when a latched message was sent over the topic. We should also set the flag if the topic receives a regular message. Otherwise it's possible to receive an old message, which is what caused the problem in the above comment.
values.title: Fix issue #1702 part 4

summary.raw:
[Jenkins nvidia](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/518)

This pull request address [this comment](#!/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/1859/issue_1702/diff#comment-9785285).

A latched subscription is designed to receive the last message sent on a topic. The flag that indicates if the subscription has received a latched message is only set when a latched message was sent over the topic. We should also set the flag if the topic receives a regular message. Otherwise it's possible to receive an old message, which is what caused the problem in the above comment.
summary.html:
Jenkins nvidia

This pull request address this comment.

A latched subscription is designed to receive the last message sent on a topic. The flag that indicates if the subscription has received a latched message is only set when a latched message was sent over the topic. We should also set the flag if the topic receives a regular message. Otherwise it's possible to receive an old message, which is what caused the problem in the above comment.

values.description:
This is based on a [design document for graphical inertia modification](#!/osrf/gazebo_design/src/default/inertia_resize/inertia_resize.md). This adds tests to confirm that modifying mass and center-of-mass location with a `~/model/modify` message will actually update the inertia. Updating the inertia matrix will follow in a subsequent pull request.

The first test `InertialAccessors` updates inertial properties with a message and verifies that the C++ API reflects the change. This tests passes with each physics engine, since it is only checking the `physics::Inertial` object.

The `SetMass` and `SetCoG` tests use the `seesaw.world`, which has a few boxes stacked together and balancing:

![seesaw.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/4131299900-seesaw.png)

One test increases the mass on one of the balanced boxes, and the other test moves the center-of-mass of the balancing plank away from the center. Each test assumes that the seesaw will tip over.

These tests require the `Link::UpdateMass` virtual function to be implemented for each physics engine. I added `BulletLink::UpdateMass`, `SimbodyLink::UpdateMass` and `DARTLink::UpdateMass` since they did not exist. I verified that the [ABI checker](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/API_ABI%20checker/job/gazebo-any_to_any-abichecker-vivid-amd64/24/API_ABI_report/) is clean.

I fixed `SetMass` for bullet in ca3b4789ed0b and for DART in b2fd97c7b7b4. As a bonus, `SetCoG` was fixed for DART by those changes as well.

The `SetCoG` test was broken for ODE; fixing it required updating all the collision offsets. Bullet will require something similar, though I haven’t attempted it yet.

For the ODE fix, I also reduced some code duplication by calling `ODELink::UpdateSurface` from `ODELink::Init` and creating `ODELink::UpdateCollisionOffsets` that could be called from `Init` and `UpdateMass`. 

I haven’t tried with Simbody. I’ll cc @sherm1 to see what he recommends.

Jenkins results:

* [ABI checker](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/API_ABI%20checker/job/gazebo-any_to_any-abichecker-vivid-amd64/24/API_ABI_report/) is clean

* [trusty no-gpu](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-no-gpu/680/) is clean

* [trusty nvidia dart4](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any_dart4-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/85) is clean

Update: more happy jenkins builds

* http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-homebrew-amd64/532/
* http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/524/
values.title: Update inertia properties during simulation: part 1

summary.raw:
This is based on a [design document for graphical inertia modification](#!/osrf/gazebo_design/src/default/inertia_resize/inertia_resize.md). This adds tests to confirm that modifying mass and center-of-mass location with a `~/model/modify` message will actually update the inertia. Updating the inertia matrix will follow in a subsequent pull request.

The first test `InertialAccessors` updates inertial properties with a message and verifies that the C++ API reflects the change. This tests passes with each physics engine, since it is only checking the `physics::Inertial` object.

The `SetMass` and `SetCoG` tests use the `seesaw.world`, which has a few boxes stacked together and balancing:

![seesaw.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/4131299900-seesaw.png)

One test increases the mass on one of the balanced boxes, and the other test moves the center-of-mass of the balancing plank away from the center. Each test assumes that the seesaw will tip over.

These tests require the `Link::UpdateMass` virtual function to be implemented for each physics engine. I added `BulletLink::UpdateMass`, `SimbodyLink::UpdateMass` and `DARTLink::UpdateMass` since they did not exist. I verified that the [ABI checker](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/API_ABI%20checker/job/gazebo-any_to_any-abichecker-vivid-amd64/24/API_ABI_report/) is clean.

I fixed `SetMass` for bullet in ca3b4789ed0b and for DART in b2fd97c7b7b4. As a bonus, `SetCoG` was fixed for DART by those changes as well.

The `SetCoG` test was broken for ODE; fixing it required updating all the collision offsets. Bullet will require something similar, though I haven’t attempted it yet.

For the ODE fix, I also reduced some code duplication by calling `ODELink::UpdateSurface` from `ODELink::Init` and creating `ODELink::UpdateCollisionOffsets` that could be called from `Init` and `UpdateMass`. 

I haven’t tried with Simbody. I’ll cc @sherm1 to see what he recommends.

Jenkins results:

* [ABI checker](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/API_ABI%20checker/job/gazebo-any_to_any-abichecker-vivid-amd64/24/API_ABI_report/) is clean

* [trusty no-gpu](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-no-gpu/680/) is clean

* [trusty nvidia dart4](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any_dart4-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/85) is clean

Update: more happy jenkins builds

* http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-homebrew-amd64/532/
* http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/524/
summary.html:
This is based on a design document for graphical inertia modification. This adds tests to confirm that modifying mass and center-of-mass location with a ~/model/modify message will actually update the inertia. Updating the inertia matrix will follow in a subsequent pull request.

The first test InertialAccessors updates inertial properties with a message and verifies that the C++ API reflects the change. This tests passes with each physics engine, since it is only checking the physics::Inertial object.

The SetMass and SetCoG tests use the seesaw.world, which has a few boxes stacked together and balancing:

One test increases the mass on one of the balanced boxes, and the other test moves the center-of-mass of the balancing plank away from the center. Each test assumes that the seesaw will tip over.

These tests require the Link::UpdateMass virtual function to be implemented for each physics engine. I added BulletLink::UpdateMass, SimbodyLink::UpdateMass and DARTLink::UpdateMass since they did not exist. I verified that the ABI checker is clean.

I fixed SetMass for bullet in ca3b4789ed0b and for DART in b2fd97c7b7b4. As a bonus, SetCoG was fixed for DART by those changes as well.

The SetCoG test was broken for ODE; fixing it required updating all the collision offsets. Bullet will require something similar, though I haven’t attempted it yet.

For the ODE fix, I also reduced some code duplication by calling ODELink::UpdateSurface from ODELink::Init and creating ODELink::UpdateCollisionOffsets that could be called from Init and UpdateMass.

I haven’t tried with Simbody. I’ll cc @sherm1 to see what he recommends.

Jenkins results:

  • ABI checker is clean

  • trusty no-gpu is clean

  • trusty nvidia dart4 is clean

Update: more happy jenkins builds

  • http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-homebrew-amd64/532/
  • http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/524/

values.description:
When running ``` gazebo actor.world``` prints errors ```Error [Element.hh:322] Unable to find value for key[self_collide]```

This does not happen with gazebo5 but happens in the latest ones, possibly due to changes in Link.cc.
The errors could be fixed by adding the "self_collide" element to the Actor links.

This commit gets rid of most of the error messages, but not all.
To get rid of all the error messages, some modification on actor.sdf (from sdformat) might be required.  
(Maybe there should be a "self_collide" element in actor.sdf, so that we can add the element before passing ```_sdf``` to ```Model::Load```?)

CC @k-okada
values.title: Found some key[self_collide] errors from Element.hh when trying Actor

summary.raw:
When running ``` gazebo actor.world``` prints errors ```Error [Element.hh:322] Unable to find value for key[self_collide]```

This does not happen with gazebo5 but happens in the latest ones, possibly due to changes in Link.cc.
The errors could be fixed by adding the "self_collide" element to the Actor links.

This commit gets rid of most of the error messages, but not all.
To get rid of all the error messages, some modification on actor.sdf (from sdformat) might be required.  
(Maybe there should be a "self_collide" element in actor.sdf, so that we can add the element before passing ```_sdf``` to ```Model::Load```?)

CC @k-okada
summary.html:
When running gazebo actor.world prints errors Error [Element.hh:322] Unable to find value for key[self_collide]

This does not happen with gazebo5 but happens in the latest ones, possibly due to changes in Link.cc. The errors could be fixed by adding the "self_collide" element to the Actor links.

This commit gets rid of most of the error messages, but not all. To get rid of all the error messages, some modification on actor.sdf (from sdformat) might be required.
(Maybe there should be a "self_collide" element in actor.sdf, so that we can add the element before passing _sdf to Model::Load?)

CC @k-okada

values.description:
Merging [sdformat pull request 224](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/224/remove-boost-part1) removed some boost includes from `sdf/Param.hh`. This [broke the gazebo build](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-default-sdformat-default-devel-trusty-amd64/50/) since there are many functions that use boost features that don't explicitly include the correct header files.

This affects the default branch, but also gazebo5 and gazebo6 (see [jenkins failure for gazebo5](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-sdformat-any-devel-trusty-amd64/39/)). I've targeted this fix to `gazebo5` and will merge it forward.

The changes are mainly adding missing header files, though I also backported changes from pull request #1888 and pull request #1748.

I ran a many jenkins jobs while testing this; here's the last one showing that the [build is fixed](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-sdformat-any-devel-trusty-amd64/46/). There are a bunch of test failures in building the examples due to missing `--std=c++11` in the `CXX_FLAGS`. I didn't add these because the examples compile correctly with this branch with sdformat2, which is the declared dependency for `gazebo5`. They only fail when compiled against `sdformat3`. If we want to fix this we can also backport pull request #1853, but I was planning to skip it.
values.title: Fix compilation with sdformat default branch

summary.raw:
Merging [sdformat pull request 224](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/224/remove-boost-part1) removed some boost includes from `sdf/Param.hh`. This [broke the gazebo build](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-default-sdformat-default-devel-trusty-amd64/50/) since there are many functions that use boost features that don't explicitly include the correct header files.

This affects the default branch, but also gazebo5 and gazebo6 (see [jenkins failure for gazebo5](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-sdformat-any-devel-trusty-amd64/39/)). I've targeted this fix to `gazebo5` and will merge it forward.

The changes are mainly adding missing header files, though I also backported changes from pull request #1888 and pull request #1748.

I ran a many jenkins jobs while testing this; here's the last one showing that the [build is fixed](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-sdformat-any-devel-trusty-amd64/46/). There are a bunch of test failures in building the examples due to missing `--std=c++11` in the `CXX_FLAGS`. I didn't add these because the examples compile correctly with this branch with sdformat2, which is the declared dependency for `gazebo5`. They only fail when compiled against `sdformat3`. If we want to fix this we can also backport pull request #1853, but I was planning to skip it.
summary.html:
Merging sdformat pull request 224 removed some boost includes from sdf/Param.hh. This broke the gazebo build since there are many functions that use boost features that don't explicitly include the correct header files.

This affects the default branch, but also gazebo5 and gazebo6 (see jenkins failure for gazebo5). I've targeted this fix to gazebo5 and will merge it forward.

The changes are mainly adding missing header files, though I also backported changes from pull request #1888 and pull request #1748.

I ran a many jenkins jobs while testing this; here's the last one showing that the build is fixed. There are a bunch of test failures in building the examples due to missing --std=c++11 in the CXX_FLAGS. I didn't add these because the examples compile correctly with this branch with sdformat2, which is the declared dependency for gazebo5. They only fail when compiled against sdformat3. If we want to fix this we can also backport pull request #1853, but I was planning to skip it.

values.description:
While working on the undo feature, I realized the state of lights is not kept on the server side. 

This pull request adds `Light` and `LightState` classes to physics, so that, besides helping with undo:

* If a light is moved while recording a log file, the movement is also reproduced during playback

* Resetting the world (Ctrl + R) also resets light poses

* Having lights be `physics::Entity` paves the way for attaching lights to links (issue #900)

Requires [SDFormat pull request #227](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/227/add-light-state/diff)

[CI gazebo any sdf any](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/CI%20any%20jobs/job/gazebo-any-sdformat-any-devel-trusty-amd64/48/)
values.title: Light and light state for the server side

summary.html:
While working on the undo feature, I realized the state of lights is not kept on the server side.

This pull request adds Light and LightState classes to physics, so that, besides helping with undo:

  • If a light is moved while recording a log file, the movement is also reproduced during playback

  • Resetting the world (Ctrl + R) also resets light poses

  • Having lights be a physics::Entity paves the way for attaching lights to links (issue #900)

Requires SDFormat pull request #227

values.description:
Output the proto path to gazebo's cmake config so that other projects (such as swarm) can make use of gazebo's proto files.

Example usage in a `CMakeLists.txt` file:

```
add_custom_command(
  OUTPUT
  "${CMAKE_CURRENT_BINARY_DIR}/${FIL_WE}.pb.cc"
  "${CMAKE_CURRENT_BINARY_DIR}/${FIL_WE}.pb.h"
  COMMAND  ${PROTOBUF_PROTOC_EXECUTABLE}
  ARGS --plugin=protoc-gen-ignmsgs=${CMAKE_CURRENT_BINARY_DIR}/${ignmsgs_out_binary} --cpp_out=dllexport_decl=IGNITION_MSGS_VISIBLE:${CMAKE_CURRENT_BINARY_DIR} --ignmsgs_out ${CMAKE_CURRENT_BINARY_DIR} --proto_path ${CMAKE_CURRENT_SOURCE_DIR} --proto_path ${GAZEBO_PROTO_PATH} ${ABS_FIL}
  DEPENDS ${ABS_FIL} ignmsgs_out
  COMMENT "Running C++ protocol buffer compiler on ${FIL}"
  VERBATIM )
```

The important part is `--proto_path ${GAZEBO_PROTO_PATH} `

[Jenkins nogpu pending](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-no-gpu/707/), but this won't break the build.

Added Insert tab to the model editor palette by reusing the `InsertModelWidget` class (the one used to insert model from the model data base in normal simulation mode)

*  Split into two classes `ModelEditorPalette` (Insert tab) `ModelTreeWidget` (Settings tab)

* Added functionality to remove nested models 

Still in the list of TODO's for nested models:

* selection, manipulation, context menu, schematic view support


[jenkins gpu](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/539/) (qt tests tests having been failing on this machine but pass locally)

values.description:
This pull requests improves the overall speed of log playback and test coverage.

* It uses `tinyxml2` in LogPlayback instead of `tinyxml`.
* Adds some new functions to `LogPlay` class: stepback, multi-step, forward, seek.

How to test it:

1. `sudo apt-get install libtinyxml2-dev`
2. Log a long Gazebo log file (+10mins).
3. Close Gazebo and open it again playing back the log file.
4. Play with the log controllers (multi-step, rewind, forward, drag and drop the temporal cursor (seek)).

Everything should be faster than before.

CI results:

* [nogpu happy](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-no-gpu/729/)
* [Mac OS X happy](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-homebrew-amd64/563/)
* [trusty nvidia happy](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/550/) (one error in gz_TEST.cc:634 but it seems unrelated).
values.title: Logging - part2

* It uses `tinyxml2` in LogPlayback instead of `tinyxml`.
* Adds some new functions to `LogPlay` class: stepback, multi-step, forward, seek.

How to test it:

1. `sudo apt-get install libtinyxml2-dev`
2. Log a long Gazebo log file (+10mins).
3. Close Gazebo and open it again playing back the log file.

summary.html:
This pull requests improves the overall speed of log playback and test coverage.

  • It uses tinyxml2 in LogPlayback instead of tinyxml.
  • Adds some new functions to LogPlay class: stepback, multi-step, forward, seek.

How to test it:

  1. sudo apt-get install libtinyxml2-dev
  2. Log a long Gazebo log file (+10mins).
  3. Close Gazebo and open it again playing back the log file.
  4. Play with the log controllers (multi-step, rewind, forward, drag and drop the temporal cursor (seek)).

Everything should be faster than before.

CI results:

  • nogpu happy
  • Mac OS X happy
  • trusty nvidia happy (one error in gz_TEST.cc:634 but it seems unrelated).

values.description:
Issue #402

First pull request related to the `undo` feature described in [this](#!/osrf/gazebo_design/src/326dbc5e7f6c283c5d5b39f767287afbf2cf6d60/undo/undo.md?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default) design document.

Undoable user commands for now are those which move models during simulation: translate, rotate, snap, align. They only work for models for now, but once pull request #1920 is merged it should work for lights too.

# Video

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GSkHaZpM1Ro

# Message passing 

## Registering new user commands

1. When a user executes a command, the class which executed the command from the gui side emits a `UserCmd` message.

2. `physics::UserCmdManager` registers the command and sends a message for the gui with the complete stats for all registered commands.

3. The gui updates itself based on the commands.

![undo10.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/1844619545-undo10.png)

## Requesting to undo / redo

1. `gui::UserCmdHistory` sends a `UndoRedo` message with the user request to undo / redo a command

2. `physics::UserCmdManager` executes the request and sends updated `USerCmdStats`

3. `gui::UserCmdHistory` updates itself based on the new stats

![undo20.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/245938902-undo20.png)
values.title: Undo user motion commands during simulation

Undoable user commands for now are those which move models during simulation: translate, rotate, snap, align. They only work for models for now, but once pull request #1920 is merged it should work for lights too.

# Video

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GSkHaZpM1Ro

# Message passing 

## Registering new user commands

1. When a user executes a command, the class which executed the command from the gui side emits a `UserCmd` message.

2. `physics::UserCmdManager` registers the command and sends a message for the gui with the complete stats for all registered commands.

3. The gui updates itself based on the commands.

![undo10.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/1844619545-undo10.png)

## Requesting to undo / redo

1. `gui::UserCmdHistory` sends a `UndoRedo` message with the user request to undo / redo a command

2. `physics::UserCmdManager` executes the request and sends updated `USerCmdStats`

3. `gui::UserCmdHistory` updates itself based on the new stats

![undo20.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/245938902-undo20.png)
summary.html:
Issue #402

First pull request related to the undo feature described in this design document.

Undoable user commands for now are those which move models during simulation: translate, rotate, snap, align. They only work for models for now, but once pull request #1920 is merged it should work for lights too.

Video

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GSkHaZpM1Ro

Message passing

Registering new user commands

  1. When a user executes a command, the class which executed the command from the gui side emits a UserCmd message.

  2. physics::UserCmdManager registers the command and sends a message for the gui with the complete stats for all registered commands.

  3. The gui updates itself based on the commands.

Requesting to undo / redo

  1. gui::UserCmdHistory sends a UndoRedo message with the user request to undo / redo a command

  2. physics::UserCmdManager executes the request and sends updated USerCmdStats

  3. gui::UserCmdHistory updates itself based on the new stats

values.description:
The `INTEGRATION_joint_gearbox` test added to resolve #1703 in pull request #1880 and pull request #1923 often fails with a timeout on OS X due to machine performance differences. The average time to complete the test on our Ubuntu machines is about 140 seconds (limit is 240), while the average on OS X is near 240. [Sometimes it passes](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any-devel-homebrew-amd64/545/testReport/(root)/ODEGearboxJoint_TEST/) (231 seconds), and [sometimes it fails](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-default-devel-homebrew-amd64-2/110/testReport/junit/(root)/INTEGRATION_joint_gearbox/test_ran/).

This PR shortens the longest test by about half. The original test iterates `j` from `[-20, 20]` by `1`; here I'm iterating by `2` to speed things up.
values.title: Shorten gearbox test since it is failing via timeout on osx

summary.raw:
The `INTEGRATION_joint_gearbox` test added to resolve #1703 in pull request #1880 and pull request #1923 often fails with a timeout on OS X due to machine performance differences. The average time to complete the test on our Ubuntu machines is about 140 seconds (limit is 240), while the average on OS X is near 240. [Sometimes it passes](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any-devel-homebrew-amd64/545/testReport/(root)/ODEGearboxJoint_TEST/) (231 seconds), and [sometimes it fails](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-default-devel-homebrew-amd64-2/110/testReport/junit/(root)/INTEGRATION_joint_gearbox/test_ran/).

This PR shortens the longest test by about half. The original test iterates `j` from `[-20, 20]` by `1`; here I'm iterating by `2` to speed things up.
summary.html:
The INTEGRATION_joint_gearbox test added to resolve #1703 in pull request #1880 and pull request #1923 often fails with a timeout on OS X due to machine performance differences. The average time to complete the test on our Ubuntu machines is about 140 seconds (limit is 240), while the average on OS X is near 240. Sometimes it passes (231 seconds), and sometimes it fails.

This PR shortens the longest test by about half. The original test iterates j from [-20, 20] by 1; here I'm iterating by 2 to speed things up.

values.description:
As discussed in #1332, the `SDF` part of `UNIT_gz_TEST` breaks whenever we release a new version of sdformat with new tags, which is quite often these days. To reduce the noise, I would propose to disable the two expectations that are expecting sdformat version `1.5` to remain constant.

Jenkins:

* [test failing on gazebo6 branch](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-gazebo_6.0-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/60/testReport/junit/%28root%29/gzTest/SDF/)
* [test fixed on this branch](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-no-gpu/743/)
values.title: Disable parts of UNIT_gz_TEST SDF test that are frequently breaking (#1332)

summary.raw:
As discussed in #1332, the `SDF` part of `UNIT_gz_TEST` breaks whenever we release a new version of sdformat with new tags, which is quite often these days. To reduce the noise, I would propose to disable the two expectations that are expecting sdformat version `1.5` to remain constant.

Jenkins:

* [test failing on gazebo6 branch](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-gazebo_6.0-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/60/testReport/junit/%28root%29/gzTest/SDF/)
* [test fixed on this branch](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-no-gpu/743/)
summary.html:
As discussed in #1332, the SDF part of UNIT_gz_TEST breaks whenever we release a new version of sdformat with new tags, which is quite often these days. To reduce the noise, I would propose to disable the two expectations that are expecting sdformat version 1.5 to remain constant.

Jenkins:

  • test failing on gazebo6 branch
  • test fixed on this branch

values.description:
We can't use "near" and "far" on windows. This will break API with gazebo6. I'm not worried about it because it's a new feature, and is used only by the swarm teams (as far as I know).

values.description:
More updates for Windows support.

1. Windows complained about `CPPTYPE_*` in `gazebo/gui/ConfigWidget.cc`, so I replaced it with `TYPE_*`.

2. KeyEvent constructor should be in a source file.

3. Removed a few visibility flags from c functions.

values.description:
# Video

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=P_kBFYr7xZg

# Changes

* Remove Apply button

* New button behaviors:

    * `Reset`: Restores the dialog and corresponding 3D elements to the state they were when the dialog was opened.

    * `Cancel`: Resets and closes the dialog.

    * `Ok`: Reapply all changes and close the dialog.

* Fields in the inspectors which have visible effects on the rest of the model editor should take effect in real time:

    * Joint: name, parent, child, type, pose, axis

    * Link: pose

    * Visual: pose, geometry, transparency, colors, material

    * Collision: pose, geometry

* Fix issue #1472

* Partial fix for #1527

* Partial fix for #402

* Moved some gui/model tests outside of ENABLE_SCREEN_TESTS so they run on Jenkins, [successfully](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/CI%20any%20jobs/job/gazebo-any-coverage-trusty-amd64/425/)
values.title: Model Editor: Apply inspector changes in real time and add reset button

summary.raw:
# Video

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=P_kBFYr7xZg

# Changes

* Remove Apply button

* New button behaviors:

    * `Reset`: Restores the dialog and corresponding 3D elements to the state they were when the dialog was opened.

    * `Cancel`: Resets and closes the dialog.

    * `Ok`: Reapply all changes and close the dialog.

* Fields in the inspectors which have visible effects on the rest of the model editor should take effect in real time:

    * Joint: name, parent, child, type, pose, axis

    * Link: pose

    * Visual: pose, geometry, transparency, colors, material

    * Collision: pose, geometry

* Fix issue #1472

* Partial fix for #1527

* Partial fix for #402

* Moved some gui/model tests outside of ENABLE_SCREEN_TESTS so they run on Jenkins, [successfully](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/CI%20any%20jobs/job/gazebo-any-coverage-trusty-amd64/425/)

    • Collision: pose, geometry

  • Fix issue #1472

  • Partial fix for #1527

  • Partial fix for #402

  • Moved some gui/model tests outside of ENABLE_SCREEN_TESTS so they run on Jenkins, successfully

Gazebo6 will be used with the RoboCup 3D simulation plugin that we're about to release this week.

[ABI-compatibility](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any_to_any-abichecker-vivid-amd64/30/) pending.

Bumping priority.

values.description:
This pull request [should fix the ABI problem](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any_to_any-abichecker-vivid-amd64/29/API_ABI_report/) we found in the [gazebo 6.3 release](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any_to_any-abichecker-vivid-amd64/28/API_ABI_report/).

The workaround is to modify the SetPose method (added to sensor class in gazebo 6.3) to make it non virtual. Since we are not overloading this method in any point of our code, the behavior in our code base should remain the same. While this is not ideal for third party code built that uses the `Sensor::SetPose` method, I think that it can work in most of the situations and keep API just the same than in 6.3.
values.title: Fix ABI breakage in gazebo6. Make Sensor SetPose non virtual.

summary.raw:
This pull request [should fix the ABI problem](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any_to_any-abichecker-vivid-amd64/29/API_ABI_report/) we found in the [gazebo 6.3 release](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any_to_any-abichecker-vivid-amd64/28/API_ABI_report/).

The workaround is to modify the SetPose method (added to sensor class in gazebo 6.3) to make it non virtual. Since we are not overloading this method in any point of our code, the behavior in our code base should remain the same. While this is not ideal for third party code built that uses the `Sensor::SetPose` method, I think that it can work in most of the situations and keep API just the same than in 6.3.
summary.html:
This pull request should fix the ABI problem we found in the gazebo 6.3 release.

The workaround is to modify the SetPose method (added to sensor class in gazebo 6.3) to make it non virtual. Since we are not overloading this method in any point of our code, the behavior in our code base should remain the same. While this is not ideal for third party code built that uses the Sensor::SetPose method, I think that it can work in most of the situations and keep API just the same than in 6.3.

values.title: fix memory corruption in transport/Publisher.cc

summary.html:
In function "SendMessage()" from file "transport/Publisher.cc", the following line can lead to memory corruption.

this->pubIds[*pubIter] = this->publication->Publish(*iter,
                boost::bind(&Publisher::OnPublishComplete, this, _1), *pubIter);

The method Publish() calls directly the callback OnPublishComplete(), which erases the map entry "this->pubIds[pubIter]". In c/c++, considering an assignment, the order of evaluation of right and left operands is not specified. Therefore the compiler can choose to evaluate first "this->pubIds[pubIter]", then executes the methode Publish(). The assignment ends up with writting in a memory area that has been disallocated.

The solution to avoid that is simple. Just split the assignment in two steps:

int result = this->publication->Publish(*iter,
                boost::bind(&Publisher::OnPublishComplete, this, _1), *pubIter);

this->pubIds[*pubIter] = result;
